title: 104_s270
content: The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" allows for the removal of alien terrorists under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" defines key terms and procedures for the removal of alien terrorists, including the use of classified information and special removal hearings. The Attorney General must certify the presence of an alien terrorist in the US for deportation. The Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995 outlines procedures for removing alien terrorists in the US, involving special court hearings based on classified information. The Attorney General certifies the presence of an alien terrorist, and a special court with designated judges decides on the case. The Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995 establishes procedures for removing alien terrorists through special court hearings with designated judges. The Chief Justice can designate judges under this act, and when the Attorney General applies for removal, a single judge considers the application in camera and ex parte, invoking special court procedures if there is probable cause to believe the alien poses a national security risk. The Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995 allows for special removal hearings for identified aliens posing a national security risk, with proceedings open to the public and the right to counsel provided for the alien. The Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995 allows for special removal hearings for aliens posing a national security risk. Aliens have the right to be represented by counsel, with counsel appointed if unable to obtain. The alien can introduce evidence, cross-examine witnesses, and request subpoenas. The judge can authorize the introduction of evidence in camera if public disclosure poses a national security risk. The judge can substitute evidence with a statement admitting relevant facts. The judge can substitute evidence with a statement admitting relevant facts or a summary if disclosure poses a risk of harm. If the substituted evidence provides the alien with the ability to make their defense, disclosure may not be necessary. If disclosure of specific evidence poses a risk of harm, the judge can substitute it with a statement or summary to allow the alien to make their defense. Deportation may be determined based on clear and convincing evidence of the alien being subject to deportation. The Attorney General must prove, with clear and convincing evidence, that the alien is subject to deportation under section 241(a)(4)(B). Appeals can be made to the court of appeals for the Federal Circuit within twenty days of the determination. The Attorney General may appeal a determination under subsections (d), (e), or (f) to the court of appeals for the Federal Circuit within twenty days. The entire record of the proceeding can be transmitted to the court of appeals under seal for consideration in camera and ex parte.
